results.title: The Legend of Jimmy Governor
results.brief_description:
Episode of ABC TV series ‘A Big Country’ exploring the real life story of Jimmy Governor, as compared to his fictional counterpart, Jimmie Blacksmith, in the novel and film, ‘The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith’. Includes interviews with author, Thomas Keneally, and film director, Fred Schepisi, on location during the making of the film.
Broadcast on ABC TV in April 1978. Reporter: Kenyon Castle. Narrator: Bob Plasto.

results.title: The Sensory world (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Joel Gold, Philip Mendlow, Tom Lazarus and CRM Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”
Examines and demonstrates the empirical mechanics of human perception or misperception of our environments and the functioning - both normal and impaired - of the human senses. Uses animation to demonstrate various phenomena of the brain and illustrates its functions. Includes explanation of experiments with optic fibres and with electrical stimulation of the human brain and the memory.
Suitable for upper secondary and teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: The Hot date
results.brief_description: A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival. A put upon adolescent is faced with the unusual problem of potential self-combustion whenever he gets nervous. As a result, his fear is palpable when it comes to his first date. His reluctance is soon overcome as things go well and he decides to invite his love into the bedroom…what happens next is surprising and hilarious!

results.title: Token economy: behavourism applied (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Elisabeth Hall, editor of Psychology Today, interviews the eminent Behaviourist, B.F. Skinner. Skinner explains, with examples, his theory of behaviour modification (“operant conditioning”) through positive and negative reinforcement. He cites the five classic examples of mistreatment, then explains the use of tokens in a program of reinforcement therapy. The director of the Adolf Meyer Centre explains how token economy is practised. Views all aspects of the Centre’s life and contrasts its extremely high success rate with the generally lower rehabilitation rate of traditional therapy. Also Bernard Wagner discusses the concept of “time out”.

results.title: Kiwis
results.creator_credit: Janet Bell, John Sparkes, Paul Williams and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Ernie Leonard, a Maori who had relinquished his traditions and heritage became chief of his tribe at the age of 55. He had been a television compere, later becoming a television producer and Ernie was able to show how he had learnt language and traditions and helped in fostering this knowledge in the young. He now produces a television program in Maori each week called ‘Koha’.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”
Elisabeth Hall, editor of Psychology Today, interviews the emminent Behaviorist, B.F. Skinner. Skinner explains, with examples, his theory of behavior modification (“operant conditioning”) through positive and negative reinforcement. He cites the five classic examples of mistreatment, then explains the use of tokens in a program of reinforcement therapy. the director of the Adolf Meyer Center explains how token economy is practised. Views all aspects of the Center’s life and contrasts its extremely high success rate with the generally lower rehabilitation rate of traditional therapy. Also Bernard Wagner discusses the concept of “time out”.

results.title: Urban poetics
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
An abstract visual narrative about 21st century modern living and the absurdity of life. Themes of urban sprawl, desolation, commercialism and the mundanity of routine and the ordinary are all explored in this short film.

results.title: Information processing (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce Hart, Carole Hart and Communication Research Media Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Using for its base a crowded noisy cocktail party as observed from a control booth, analyses how people process information. Pretty girls and bizarrely dressed men demonstrate attention, language processing, long and short term memory, mnemonics, retrieval strategies, and problem solving.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Hart, Carole Hart and Communication Research Media Productions
